title: Post-Cholecystectomy Bile Leak
diagnosis_topic: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or accessory duct after gallbladder removal
setup_script: A 52-year-old woman is postoperative day 3 after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. She reports worsening abdominal pain and nausea. Her surgical drain output has increased and appears bilious. How would you proceed in evaluating and managing this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 115/75 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 38 °C.
Mild distension, right upper quadrant tenderness, no frank peritonitis.
300 mL bilious output in past 24 hours.
WBC 14,000/µL, total bilirubin 2.2 mg/dL, stable liver enzymes.
Nonspecific fluid near liver bed, drain in place.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan with IV and oral contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Fluid collection near gallbladder fossa; no evidence of major duct transection.
Demonstrates bile leak near cystic duct stump.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults GI for ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: ERCP identifies cystic duct stump leak; sphincterotomy and biliary stent placed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO and starts broad-spectrum antibiotics
If resident asks about percutaneous drainage
dynamic_flow.reply: IR drains biloma under image guidance.
Patient develops worsening abdominal pain, hypotension, bile peritonitis requiring reoperation.
Mentions inadequate cystic duct clip, accessory duct of Luschka, or clip slippage.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses timing of stent removal
dynamic_flow.reply: Typically 4–6 weeks after ERCP once leak healed.
Ongoing drain monitoring, serial LFTs, monitoring for recurrent leak or cholangitis.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of postoperative bile leak via drain output and symptoms
Use of imaging and ERCP to diagnose and treat leak
Decision for biliary stenting and percutaneous drainage
Prevention of bile peritonitis through early intervention

rubric.resident_feedback_template: StrengthsYou demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by identifying a bile leak based on drain output and symptoms. You appropriately utilized imaging and ERCP for diagnosis and treatment, and your management plan incorporated multidisciplinary care. Areas for ImprovementYou should further refine your discussion of the mechanisms of bile leak and expand on long-term monitoring and stent management. Clarifying your sequence of interventions in unstable patients would improve your clinical judgment.
